{{more footnotes|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox civil conflict | title = Doctors' riot | partof = | image = File:An_Interrupted_Dissection.jpg | caption = An Interrupted Dissection | date = April 1788 | place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | coordinates = | causes = Theft of corpses by doctors | goals = | methods = | status = | result = | side1 = | side2 = | side3 = | leadfigures1 = | leadfigures2 = | leadfigures3 = | howmany1 = | howmany2 = | howmany3 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | fatalities = 6-20 | injuries = | arrests = | detentions = | charged = | fined = | casualties_label = | notes = | sidebox = }}
The '''Doctors' riot''' was an incident that occurred in April 1788 in [[New York City]], where the [[body snatching|illegal procurement of corpses]] from the graves of slaves and poor whites resulted in a mass expression of discontent from poorer New Yorkers directed primarily at [[physician]]s and [[medicine|medical students]].
==Background==
By the end of the [[American Revolution]], roughly one fifth of New York City's population was [[Black Americans|black]], most of whom were [[slavery in the United States|slaves]]. The construction of New York City, under both the [[New Amsterdam|Dutch]] and the [[British colonization of the Americas|English]], was accomplished largely with slave labor. Due to their low social standing, the bodies of slaves could only be buried outside the city limits. Most often they were buried in a few plots north of [[Chambers Street (Manhattan)|Chambers Street]], across the street from the [[Pauper's Cemetery]], often with several bodies to a grave, in a site now marked by the [[African Burial Ground National Monument]], then known as the "Negroes Burying Ground".
Both cemeteries were close to [[Columbia College, Columbia University|Columbia College]], which housed the city's only school of medicine. Due to taboos associated with the violation of corpses, procuring cadavers for study was difficult, and many students and doctors would exhume bodies from the nearby graveyards, due to the socially marginalized status of their occupants. “Resurrection”, as [[Body snatching|body-snatching]] or [[Grave robbery|grave-robbing]] was called, was the cheapest, surest way to obtain the remains of the newly deceased, especially in the winter when bodies decayed slower.<ref>{{cite journal|year=2011|title=American resurrection and the 1788 New York doctors' riot|url=|journal=The Lancet|volume=377|issue=9762|pages=292–293|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(11)60083-4|author1=Caroline de Costa|author2=Francesca Miller}}</ref>
==The riot== [[File:HEADLEY(1882) -p080 New York Hospital - scene of the Doctors' Riot.jpg|thumb|300px|[[New York Hospital]], scene of the riot.]] Because there was, at the time, no known method of preserving an entire corpse, thefts were performed hastily, often in winter to slow the rate of decomposition. In the winter of 1788, the number of corpses being exhumed by students increased substantially. The activities of medical students and physicians, who were known colloquially as ''Resurrectionists'' in the Black cemetery, were noticed by a group of [[freedmen]] who, on February the 3rd, petitioned the [[New York City Council|Common Council]] to take action against it. The petition was largely ignored, and no effort was made to stop the unlicensed exhumations.
In April 1788, a group of children were playing outside the New York Hospital, next to a room where a student of the physician [[Richard Bayley]], who was known to exhume corpses from the two cemeteries, was dissecting an arm. Bayley, born and bred in Connecticut, had received his medical education in England, where body-snatching was more common. There were whispers about him “cutting up his patients and performing cruel experiments upon the sick”.
The student, named John Hicks, waved the arm out at the children, telling a boy whose mother had recently died that it belonged to her. The boy ran home and told his father of this, who, after exhuming his wife's coffin and finding it empty, amassed a group of concerned citizens who marched to the hospital and began to mass around the building.
The mob eventually broke into the hospital and, after becoming incensed upon finding several bodies in various stages of mutilation, pulled Richard Bayley's assistant [[Wright Post]] and a number of his students into the street, where the mayor of New York City, [[James Duane (Continental Congress)|James Duane]] intervened and ordered them escorted to the jailhouse for protection.
A crowd of 2,000 people had gathered, and news spread of the horrors seen in the hospital, leading to widespread rioting, with the few physicians remaining in New York City being forced into hiding. A large group of rioters descended upon [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]], searching for John Hicks, who was felt by the crowd to be the main source of blame. As they assembled in front of the courthouse, throwing rocks, militia and cavalry were called in to repel them. The riot lasted a few days, ceasing when Governor Clinton sent the militia to patrol the streets until a calm environment was ensured.
At least three rioters and three militiamen died in the confrontation; some estimate up to 20 dead.<ref>Bess Lovejoy.[http://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/gory-new-york-city-riot-shaped-american-medicine-180951766/ "The Gory New York City Riot that Shaped American Medicine"].2014.</ref> The protesters also destroyed all the available human specimens.
==Effects==
Public opinion of the physicians in New York stood very low for many years, and while some students were brought to trial, Hicks was not among them. Post-mortem dissection was considered an indignity to the dead and the city fathers even forbade using bodies abandoned in the rougher parts of the city. A year later, in January 1789, a statute was finally put into law in order to codify the proper treatment of corpses, with harsh punishments imposed for those who violated it. Anyone who broke the law would stand on the pillory or be publicly whipped, fined, or imprisoned.
The statute also permitted the bodies of executed criminals to be used in dissection, “in order that science [might not] be injured by preventing the dissection of proper subjects”. “Resurrection men”, professionals who used stealth and discretion, were recruited to replace the students and went on to control the supply of cadavers for generations. Throughout the 1700s, British law considered dissection as a worse punishment than death.
To discourage dueling, the Massachusetts General Court also imposed dissection as a threat by ruling that anyone who died as a result of a duel would be sentenced to post-mortem dissection and dismemberment. Dissection was seen as perhaps one of the worst things that could happen to a person after death.

4 civilians wounded | notes = | campaignbox = }} The '''1989 attack on La Tablada barracks''' was an assault on the military [[barracks]] located in [[La Tablada, Buenos Aires|La Tablada]], in the [[provinces of Argentina|province]] of [[Buenos Aires Province|Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]], by 40 members of ''[[Movimiento Todos por la Patria]]'' (MTP), commanded by former [[People's Revolutionary Army (Argentina)|ERP]] leader [[Enrique Gorriarán Merlo]]. 39 people were killed and 60 injured by the time the Argentine army retook the barracks. The MTP carried out the assault under the false pretense of preventing a military coup, allegedly planned for the end of January 1989 by the ''[[Carapintadas]]'', a group of [[far-right]] military officers opposed to the investigations concerning the "[[Dirty War]]". The Argentine president of the time, [[Raúl Alfonsín]] declared that the attack, with the ultimate goal of sparking a massive popular uprising, could have led to civil war.[https://books.google.com/books?id=E5arAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA119&dq=alfonsin+declared+that+the+attack+could+have+led+to+civil+war The Politics of Human Rights in Argentina: Protest, Change, and Democratization, [[Alison Brysk]], p. 119, Stanford University Press, 1994] Given a [[life sentence]] and imprisoned, as his comrades, in [[Supermax|high security quarters]], Gorriarán Merlo was eventually freed in 2003.[[Comisión Interamericana de Derechos Humanos]]. [http://www.cidh.org/annualrep/97span/Argentina11.137.htm Informe Nº 55/97 - Caso 11.137][[Human Rights Watch]]. [https://www.hrw.org/reports/1989/WR89/Argentin.htm 1989 Argentina report] He died on 22 September 2006 while awaiting surgery for an [[abdominal aortic aneurysm]]. == The assault on the barracks == On 23 January 1989, a group of approximatively 40 members of the ''[[Movimiento Todos por la Patria]]'' ("''All for the Motherland''" Movement, "MTP", founded in 1986 by former [[People's Revolutionary Army (Argentina)|ERP]] leader [[Enrique Gorriarán Merlo]]) attacked the 3rd Mechanized Infantry Regiment barracks in La Tablada (''Regimiento de Infantería Mecanizada Nº 3'', RIM3). They broke into the barracks by ramming a stolen truck into the main gate, followed by several other vehicles. According to ''[[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]]'' newspaper, three different versions about the attack exist.{{cite news |newspaper=Clarín |url=http://www.clarin.com/diario/2004/01/23/p-01403.htm |title=El ataque a La Tablada, la última aventura de la guerrilla argentina |date=23 January 2004 |language=Spanish}} Ten days before the assault, lawyer and MTP member Jorge Baños had declared in a conference that the ''[[Carapintadas]]'' were planning a [[coup]] for the end of January. The ''Carapintadas'' were members of the Armed Forces that had rebelled against the national government three times in 1987 and 1988, protesting the investigations on [[human rights]] abuses during the "[[National Reorganization Process]]" (1976–1983). This has remained to this day the MTP's version, held in particular by the late Gorriarán Merlo who claimed that the MTP was fulfilling the [[Constitution of Argentina|constitutional]] obligation of "''bear[ing] arms in defense of the fatherland and of [the] Constitution''".{{cite web |publisher=Taringa!. |url=http://www.taringa.net/posts/110886/Copamiento-al-cuartel-de-La-Tablada.html |title=Copamiento al cuartel de La Tablada |language=Spanish}}[[Constitution of Argentina|Constitution of the Argentine Nation]], Article 21. "''Every Argentine citizen is obliged to bear arms in defense of the fatherland and of this Constitution…''" [[File:Alfonsin la tablada.jpg|thumb|left|250px|President [[Raúl Alfonsín]] (in pale suit) visits the site, where an MTP member lies after being killed by the Army]] The official report on the attack by head of the Army Francisco Gassino claimed in contrary that it was the MTP, formed of several former ERP members, that had planned a coup. A last version claims that the MTP was victim of a manipulation by [[Sistema de Inteligencia Nacional|intelligence services]]. A sociologist and professor who published an investigation into the attack believes the MTP had wider aims: ''"They weren’t planning to put down a coup. They were creating the false image of a coup, to set the scene, but were planning to take the barracks and from there start a revolution."''[https://archive.is/20090814042252/http://www.theargentimes.com/feature/la-tablada-the-guerrillas-last-stand-/ La Tablada – the Guerrillas’ Last Stand] The [[Argentine Army]], assisted by the [[Policía Bonaerense|Buenos Aires Police]] (a total of 3,600 personnel) was called on to counterattack, and indiscriminately used [[White phosphorus (weapon)|white phosphorus]] (WP) in the zone, in violation of the [[Geneva Conventions]], which in civil wars are only binding with the consent of both parties, and not at all in police actions. The use of WP in combat is forbidden by [[international law]]. In this case, it had the effect of completely burning the barracks and of carbonizing corpses.{{cite web |url=http://www.unhchr.ch/Huridocda/Huridoca.nsf/0/298628a9022c5e06c12569fb00576635?|title=OpenDocument E/CN.4/2001/NGO/98 |publisher=United Nations |date=12 January 2001 |accessdate=9 February 2007 |language=Spanish}}[[Agenzia Nazionale Stampa Associata|ANSA]] cable quoted by [[RAI|RaiNews]]24: [http://www.rainews24.rai.it/ran24/inchiesta/testimonianze.asp Alcune testimonianze sull'uso militare del fosforo bianco] {{it icon}}. 39 people were killed and 60 injured during the attack (the majority by conventional weapons). Nine were military personnel, two were police officers and the 28 remaining were members of the MTP. Lawyer Jorge Baños was among the dead.''La Historia Pensada''. [http://www.lahistoriapensada.com.ar/index.php?id=61 ''Asalto al cuartel General Belgrano (La Tablada)'']{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. September 17, 2006 {{es icon}}. In addition, 53 soldiers and police were wounded in the fighting.{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,956889,00.html |title=Argentina The Battle of La Tablada |publisher=TIME Magazine |date=6 February 1989}} The following day, President [[Raúl Alfonsín]] ([[Radical Civic Union|UCR]], 1983–89) visited the site, protected by Argentine Army commandos, along with federal the judge of [[Morón]], Gerardo Larrambebere, who is today member of the court presiding over the 1994 [[AMIA bombing]] case. == Alleged human rights violations == Retired sergeant José Almada, who had participated in the capture of the MTP members, declared in 2004 that Iván Ruiz and José Díaz had been tortured. According to sergeant Almada, they referred to two persons who were not members of their brigade, and most probably [[SIDE]] agents. He identified one of them as Jorge Varando, chief of security of [[HSBC]] corporation in Buenos Aires during the [[December 2001 riots (Argentina)|December 2001 events]]. Furthermore, sergeant Almada declared that he had clearly heard a radio conversation ordering to kill two of the captured prisoners. He also said that adjutant sergeant Esquivel, killed during the attack, had been in fact shot by the Army itself, after trying to get to his brother who had been taken prisoner. Sergeant Almada explicitly denounced the [[Organization of American States|OAS]] report written by Jorge Varando and General Arrillaga, the highest-ranking official in charge of the repression, which aimed at disguising adjutant sergeant Esquivel's suspicious death.{{cite news |url=http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/elpais/1-31720-2004-02-20.html |title=Mi verdad sobre La Tablada es irrefutable |date=20 February 2004 |newspaper=Página/12 |language=Spanish}} José Almada said that he had tried to inform his hierarchy about these [[human rights violations]], in accordance with article 194 of the Military Justice Code, but that they ignored him. He notably tried to inform General Martín Balza. He also informed head of Argentine Army, General [[Bonifacio Cáceres]], also telling him about his concerns that his neighbours were insulting him, saying that they were responsible of new cases of ''desaparecidos''. Moreover, in his complaint before justice, he also said he had informed former head of the Army [[Ricardo Brinzoni]]. After Cáceres's retirement in 1989, colonel Gasquet threatened José Almada of 40 days of arrest — he was finally given two days of arrest on charges of wearing a beard, and then sent him to [[Paraná, Entre Ríos]]. Later, he was again sentenced to 30 days of arrest, confined to [[Crespo, Entre Ríos|Crespo]] near Paraná and finally forced to retire. He still claims to this day he is still being "persecuted." The MTP guerrillas were also accused of human right violations. As a conscript serving in the 3rd Infantry Regiment, Eduardo Navascues was taken prisoner early in the assault and suffered shrapnel wounds in the fighting that followed. Despite having been shot several years later in an attempt to silence him, he has given testimony in a recent court case alleging [[human rights abuses]] including physical and mental torture at the hand of the guerrillas.[http://www.notife.com/noticia/articulo/975240/La_Tablada_niegan_que_una_atacante_haya_sido_fusilada.html ''Niegan que una atacante haya sido fusilada''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714203114/http://www.notife.com/noticia/articulo/975240/La_Tablada_niegan_que_una_atacante_haya_sido_fusilada.html |date=2011-07-14 }} ''Diario Digital de Santa Fe'', 11 de agosto de 2009 {{es icon}} Another conscript, Private Víctor Eduardo Scarafiocco claimed that he and others were used as human shields by the guerrillas and that Private Héctor Cardozo was killed as a result.[http://www.derf.com.ar/despachos.asp?cod_des=300517&ID_Seccion=53 ''Crónica de un olvido''] {{es icon}} == Convictions == Twenty surviving members of the MTP were later convicted and given sentences ranging from 10 years to life imprisonment. They were judged under the ''[[Ley de Defensa de la Democracia (Argentina)]]'' (Defense of the Democracy Act) which deprive them of a right to [[Court of appeal|appeal]] and to a new trial. Enrique Gorriarán Merlo was given a [[life sentence]], and his ex-wife, Ana María Sívori, was sentenced to 18 years of imprisonment. During the oral and public trial, Gorriarán put into question the legitimacy of the process and objected to the circumstances of his capture in the suburbs of [[Mexico city|Mexico]] in October 1995, which he called a "[[kidnapping]]". He was charged with being co-author of qualified [[illicit association]], [[rebellion]], [[usurpation]], [[homicide]] with aggravated circumstances, aggravated illegal privation of freedom and reiterated injuries. His ex-wife Sívori was charged with being co-author of qualified illicit association, and secondary participant to offenses of rebellion, doubly aggravated homicide, tentative of homicide, aggravated theft, reiterated injuries and co-author of the use of [[false identity documents]]. Most of those convicted in the attacks were placed in a [[Supermax|maximum security cell block]] on the eighteenth floor of the [[Caseros prison]] in [[Buenos Aires]].[http://www.web.amnesty.org/library/Index/ESLAMR130011991?open&of=ESL-ARG ''Seguimiento de la investigación criminal sobre el ataque al cuartel del Regimiento de Infantería Mecanizada III de La Tablada''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060405203743/http://web.amnesty.org/library/Index/ESLAMR130011991?open&of=ESL-ARG |date=2006-04-05 }} {{es icon}}[[Amnesty International]]. [http://web.amnesty.org/library/Index/engAMR130122000?OpenDocument&of=COUNTRIES%5CARGENTINA ''Argentina: bringing the law into line with international obligations — a challenge for the legislators''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071116230849/http://web.amnesty.org/library/Index/engAMR130122000?OpenDocument&of=COUNTRIES%5CARGENTINA |date=2007-11-16 }}. Finally, President [[Fernando de la Rúa]] ([[Alliance for Work, Justice and Education]], 1999–2001) commuted the prison sentences. And two days before [[Néstor Kirchner]]'s access to his functions, Interim President [[Eduardo Duhalde]] (member of the [[Justicialist Party]]) freed Gorriarán Merlo, on 23 May 2003, after 14 years of prison in high security quarters, who declared that it was "an act of justice". Gorriarán Merlo died of a [[cardiac arrest]] at the [[Hospital Argerich]] in Buenos Aires, while he was about to be operated of an [[abdominal aortic aneurysm]], on 22 September 2006, at the age of 64.Clarín, 22 September 2006. [http://www.clarin.com/diario/2006/09/22/um/m-01276448.htm ''Murió el ex líder guerrillero Gorriarán Merlo''] {{es icon}} == References == {{Reflist|2}} == See also == {{Commons category}} * [[History of Argentina]] * [[Carapintadas]] * [[Enrique Gorriarán Merlo]] * [[Dirty War]] * [[People's Revolutionary Army (Argentina)|ERP]] * [[White phosphorus (weapon)]] {{Coord|34|41|56|S|58|32|10|W|display=title}} {{Raúl Alfonsín}} [[Category:Presidency of Raúl Alfonsín]] [[Category:1989 in Argentina|Attack]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1989]] [[Category:Terrorist incidents in Argentina]] [[Category:Combat incidents]] [[Category:Attacks on military installations]]

{{good article}} {{Infobox Aircraft accident |image = NTSB-N47BA-slide0013 background.jpg |caption = N47BA before its final flight. |date = {{Start date |1999|10|25}} |type = [[Hypoxia (medical)|Crew incapacitation]] due to decompression, cause undetermined |occurrence_type = Accident |site = [[Edmunds County, South Dakota|Edmunds County]], [[South Dakota]], U.S.
(near [[Aberdeen, South Dakota|Aberdeen]] and [[Mina, South Dakota|Mina]]) | Coordinates = {{coord|45|25|00|N|98|45|00|W|display=inline,title}} |aircraft_type = [[Learjet 35/36|Learjet 35]] |operator = SunJet Aviation | tail_number = N47BA |origin = [[Orlando International Airport|Orlando]], [[Florida]], U.S. |destination = [[Dallas Love Field]], [[Texas]], U.S. |passengers = 4 |crew = 2 |survivors = 0 |fatalities = 6 (all dead before crash) }} On October 25, 1999, a chartered [[Learjet 35/36|Learjet 35]] was scheduled to fly from [[Orlando International Airport|Orlando]], [[Florida]], to [[Dallas Love Field|Dallas]], [[Texas]]. Early in the flight, the aircraft, which was climbing to its assigned altitude on [[autopilot]], quickly lost cabin pressure and all six on board were incapacitated due to [[Hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]] – a lack of oxygen. The aircraft continued climbing past its assigned altitude, then failed to make the westward turn toward Dallas over north Florida and continued on its northwestern course, flying over the southern and [[Midwestern United States|midwestern]] [[United States]] for almost four hours and {{convert|1500|mi}}. The plane ran out of fuel over [[South Dakota]] and crashed into a field near [[Aberdeen, South Dakota|Aberdeen]] after an [[Spiral dive|uncontrolled descent]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/news/events/Pages/Learjet_Model_35_N47BA_near_Aberdeen_South_Dakota_October_25_1999.aspx|title=Board Meeting : Learjet Model 35, N47BA, near Aberdeen, South Dakota, October 25, 1999.|date=|publisher=Ntsb.gov|accessdate=2009-08-01}} The two pilots were Michael Kling and Stephanie Bellegarrigue. The four passengers on board were [[PGA Tour|PGA]] [[golf]]er [[Payne Stewart]]; his agents, Van Ardan and Robert Fraley; and [[Bruce Borland]], a golf architect with the [[Jack Nicklaus]] golf course design company. ==Flight chronology== :''Note: all times are presented in 24-hour, military format. Because the flight took place in both the [[Eastern Time Zone|Eastern]] time zone'' – Eastern Daylight Time (EDT) – ''and the [[Central Time zone]]'' – Central Daylight Time (CDT) – ''all times are given in this article in [[Coordinated Universal Time]] (which is indicated by the time followed by the letter Z)'' ===Departure=== [[Image:NTSB-N47BA-slide0046 image002.jpg|thumb|260px|Projected (in green) and actual (in red) [[ground track]] of N47BA from departure in Orlando to Dallas and to crash site in South Dakota.]] On October 25, 1999, Learjet 35, [[Aircraft registration|registration]] {{Airreg|N|47BA|,}} operated by Sunjet Aviation of [[Sanford, Florida]], departed [[Orlando International Airport]] {{Airport codes|MCO|KMCO}} at 1319Z (0919 EDT) on a two-day, five-flight trip. Before departure, the aircraft had been fueled with {{convert|5300|lb|abbr=on}} of [[Jet fuel|Jet A]], enough for 4 hours and 45 minutes of flight. On board were two pilots and four passengers. At 1327:13Z, the [[Air traffic controller|controller]] from the [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]] [[Area Control Center|ARTCC]] instructed the pilot to climb and maintain [[flight level]] (FL) 390 ({{convert|39000|ft|-2}} above sea level). At 1327:18Z (0927:18 EDT), the pilot acknowledged the clearance by stating, "three nine zero bravo alpha." This was the last known radio transmission from the airplane, and occurred while the aircraft was passing through {{convert|23000|ft|-2}}. The next attempt to contact the aircraft occurred six minutes, 20 seconds later (14 minutes after departure), with the aircraft at {{convert|36500|ft|-2}}, and the controller's message went unacknowledged. The controller attempted to contact N47BA five more times in the next {{Frac|4|1|2}} minutes, again with no answer. ===First interception=== About 1454Z (now 0954 CDT due to the flight's crossing into the Central Time zone), a [[United States Air Force|U.S. Air Force]] [[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon|F-16]] [[test pilot]] from the [[40th Flight Test Squadron]] at [[Eglin Air Force Base|Eglin AFB]] in western Florida, who happened to be in the air nearby, was directed by controllers to intercept N47BA. When the fighter was about {{convert|2000|ft|-2}} from the Learjet, at an altitude of about {{convert|46400|ft}}, the test pilot made two radio calls to N47BA but did not receive a response. The F-16 pilot made a visual inspection of the Lear, finding no visible damage to the airplane. Both engines were running, and the plane's red rotating anti-collision beacon was on (standard operation for aircraft in flight). The fighter pilot could not see inside the passenger section of the airplane because the windows seemed to be dark. Further, he stated that the entire right cockpit windshield was [[Opacity (optics)|opaque]], as if condensation or ice covered the inside. He also indicated that the left cockpit windshield was opaque, although several sections of the center of the windshield seemed to be only thinly covered by condensation or ice; a small rectangular section of the windshield was clear, with only a small section of the glare shield visible through this area. He did not see any flight control movement. At about 1512Z, the F-16 pilot concluded his inspection of N47BA and broke formation, proceeding to [[Scott Air Force Base|Scott AFB]] in southwestern [[Illinois]]. ===Second interception=== At 1613Z, almost three hours into the flight of the unresponsive Learjet, two F-16s from the [[138th Fighter Wing]] of the [[Oklahoma Air National Guard]] (ANG), flying under the call-sign "TULSA 13 flight", were directed by the [[Minneapolis]] [[Area Control Center|ARTCC]] to intercept. The TULSA 13 lead pilot reported that he could not see any movement in the cockpit, that the windshield was dark and that he could not tell if the windshield was iced. A few minutes later, a TULSA 13 pilot reported, "We're not seeing anything inside, could be just a dark cockpit though...he is not reacting, moving or anything like that he should be able to have seen us by now." At 1639Z, TULSA 13 left to rendezvous with a tanker for [[Aerial refueling|refueling]]. The aircraft reached a maximum altitude of {{convert|48900|ft|mi km|1}}.{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/national/daily/oct99/crash26.htm |title=Golfer Payne Stewart Dies in Jet Crash |author1=Edward Walsh |author2=William Claiborne |publisher=Washington Post |date=1999-10-26 |accessdate=2007-04-19}} Appeared on page A1. ===Third interception and escort=== About 1650Z, two F-16s from the [[119th Wing]] of the [[North Dakota Air National Guard|North Dakota ANG]] with the identification "NODAK 32 flight" were directed to intercept N47BA. TULSA 13 flight also returned from refueling, and all four fighters maneuvered close to the Lear. The TULSA 13 lead pilot reported, "We've got two visuals on it. It's looking like the cockpit window is iced over and there's no displacement in any of the control surfaces as far as the [[aileron]]s or [[Trim tab|trims]]." About 1701Z, TULSA 13 flight returned to the tanker again, while NODAK 32 remained with N47BA. There was some speculation in the media that military jets were prepared to shoot down the Lear if it threatened to crash in a heavily populated area.{{citation needed|date=November 2010}} Officials at [[the Pentagon]] strongly denied that possibility. Shooting down the plane "was never an option," Air Force spokesman Captain Joe Della Vedova said, "I don't know where that came from."{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/US/9910/25/wayward.jet.07/ |title=Investigators arrive at Payne Stewart crash site |accessdate=2007-01-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080323141834/http://www.cnn.com/US/9910/25/wayward.jet.07/ |archivedate=2008-03-23 |df= }} ===Crash=== [[Image:Ntsb-N47BA-scene-1.jpg|thumb|The crash's crater
(from [[National Transportation Safety Board|NTSB]] presentation)]] [[Image:NTSB-N47BA-slide0026 background.jpg|thumb|Crash scene (from [[National Transportation Safety Board|NTSB]] presentation)]] The Learjet's [[Cockpit voice recorder|cockpit voice recorder (CVR)]], which was recovered from the wreckage, contained an audio recording of the last 30 minutes of the flight (it was an older model which only recorded 30 minutes of audio; the aircraft was not equipped with a [[flight data recorder]]). At 1710:41Z, the Learjet's engines can be heard winding down, indicating that the plane's fuel had been exhausted. In addition, sounds of the [[stick shaker]] and [[autopilot]] disconnect can be heard. With the engines powered down, the autopilot would have attempted to maintain altitude, causing the plane's [[airspeed]] to drop until it approached [[Stall (flight)|stall]] speed, at which point the stick shaker would have automatically engaged to warn the pilot and the autopilot would have switched itself off. At 1711:01Z, the Lear began a right turn and descent. NODAK 32 remained to the west, while TULSA 13 broke away from the tanker and followed N47BA down. At 1711:26 CDT, the NODAK 32 lead pilot reported, "The target is descending and he is doing multiple [[aileron roll]]s, looks like he's out of control...in a severe descent, request an emergency descent to follow target." The TULSA 13 pilot reported, "It's soon to impact the ground; he is in a descending spiral." The fighter planes were forced to break off their pursuit at this point and had to land at local airports, having reached the limit of their endurance.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} Impact occurred approximately 1713Z, or 1213 local, after a total flight time of 3 hours, 54 minutes, with the aircraft hitting the ground at a nearly supersonic speed and an extreme angle.{{cite web|author=Ray Smith |url=http://www.ntsb.gov/Speeches/former/hall/jhc001128.htm |title=NTSB Board presentation |publisher=Ntsb.gov |date= |accessdate=2009-08-01| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090902162137/http://ntsb.gov/speeches/former/hall/jhc001128.htm| archivedate= 2 September 2009 | deadurl= yes}} The Learjet crashed in South Dakota, just outside Mina in [[Edmunds County, South Dakota|Edmunds County]], on relatively flat ground and left a crater {{convert|42|ft}} long, {{convert|21|ft}} wide, and {{convert|8|ft}} deep. None of its components remained intact. == Passengers and crew == In addition to [[Payne Stewart]] and three others, there were two pilots on board: The 42-year-old captain, Michael Kling, held an [[Pilot certification in the United States#Airline transport pilot|airline transport pilot certificate]] and [[Pilot certification in the United States|type ratings]] for the [[Boeing 707]], [[Boeing 737]], and [[Learjet 35]]. He also had Air Force experience flying the [[Boeing KC-135 Stratotanker|KC-135]] and [[Boeing E-3 Sentry]]. Kling was also an instructor pilot on the KC-135E in the [[Maine Air National Guard]]. According to Sunjet Aviation records, the captain had accumulated a total of 4,280 hours of flight time (military and commercial) and had flown a total of 60 hours with Sunjet, 38 as a Learjet pilot-in-command and 22 as a Learjet second-in-command. The first officer, 27-year-old Stephanie Bellegarrigue, held a [[Pilot certification in the United States#Commercial|commercial pilot certificate]] and type ratings for Learjet and Cessna Citation 500. She was also a certified flight instructor. She had accumulated a total of 1,751 hours of flight time, of which 251 hours were with Sunjet Aviation as a second-in-command and 99 as a Learjet second-in-command. == Investigation == The [[National Transportation Safety Board|National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB)]] has several levels of investigation, of which the highest is a "major" investigation. Because of the extraordinary circumstances in this crash, a major investigation was performed.{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/ntsb/major.asp |title=NTSB Major Investigations summary web page |publisher=Ntsb.gov |date= |accessdate=2009-08-01| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090826051459/http://www.ntsb.gov/ntsb/major.asp| archivedate= 26 August 2009 | deadurl= yes}} The NTSB determined that: {{quote|The probable cause of this accident was incapacitation of the flight crew members as a result of their failure to receive supplemental oxygen following a loss of cabin pressurization, for undetermined reasons.}} The Board added a commentary regarding the possible reasons why the crew did not obtain supplemental oxygen: {{quote|Following the depressurization, the pilots did not receive supplemental oxygen in sufficient time and/or adequate concentration to avoid [[hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]] and incapacitation. The wreckage indicated that the oxygen bottle pressure regulator/shutoff valve was open on the accident flight. Further, although one flight crew mask hose connector was found in the wreckage disconnected from its valve receptacle (the other connector was not recovered), damage to the recovered connector and both receptacles was consistent with both flight crew masks having been connected to the airplane's oxygen supply lines at the time of impact. In addition, both flight crew mask microphones were found plugged into their respective crew microphone jacks. Therefore, assuming the oxygen bottle contained an adequate supply of oxygen, supplemental oxygen should have been available to both pilots' [[oxygen mask]]s. [A] possible explanation for the failure of the pilots to receive emergency oxygen is that their ability to think and act decisively was impaired because of hypoxia before they could don their oxygen masks. No definitive evidence exists that indicates the rate at which the accident flight lost its cabin pressure; therefore, the Safety Board evaluated conditions of both rapid and gradual depressurization. If there had been a breach in the fuselage (even a small one that could not be visually detected by the in-flight observers) or a seal failure, the cabin could have depressurized gradually, rapidly, or even explosively. Research has shown that a period of as little as 8 seconds without supplemental oxygen following rapid depressurization to about {{convert|30000|ft|m}} may cause a drop in oxygen saturation that can significantly impair cognitive functioning and increase the amount of time required to complete complex tasks. A more gradual decompression could have resulted from other possible causes, such as a smaller leak in the pressure vessel or a closed flow control valve. Safety Board testing determined that a closed flow control valve would cause complete depressurization to the airplane's flight altitude over a period of several minutes. However, without supplemental oxygen, substantial adverse effects on cognitive and motor skills would have been expected soon after the first clear indication of decompression (the cabin altitude warning), when the cabin altitude reached {{Convert|10000|ft|m}} (which could have occurred in about 30 seconds). Investigations of other accidents in which flight crews attempted to diagnose a pressurization problem or initiate emergency pressurization instead of immediately donning oxygen masks following a cabin altitude alert have revealed that, even with a relatively gradual rate of depressurization, pilots have rapidly lost cognitive or motor abilities to effectively troubleshoot the problem or don their masks shortly thereafter. In this accident, the flight crew's failure to obtain supplemental oxygen in time to avoid incapacitation could be explained by a delay in donning oxygen masks; of only a few seconds in the case of an explosive or rapid decompression, or a slightly longer delay in the case of a gradual decompression. In summary, the Safety Board was unable to determine why the flight crew could not, or did not, receive supplemental oxygen in sufficient time and/or adequate concentration to avoid hypoxia and incapacitation. }} The NTSB report showed that the plane had several instances of maintenance work related to cabin pressure in the months leading up to the accident. The NTSB was unable to determine whether they stemmed from a common problem – replacements and repairs were documented, but not the pilot discrepancy reports that prompted them or the frequency of such reports. The report criticised Sunjet Aviation for the possibility that this would have made the problem harder to identify, track, and resolve, as well as the fact that in at least one instance the plane was flown with an unauthorized maintenance deferral for cabin pressure problems. == Aftermath == Stewart was ultimately headed to [[Houston]] for the 1999 [[The Tour Championship|Tour Championship]], but planned a stop in Dallas for discussions with [[SMU Mustangs|the athletic department]] of his alma mater, [[Southern Methodist University]], about building a new home course for the school's golf program.{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/golf/usopen09/news/story?id=4260509 |title=In his father's footsteps |work=[[Outside the Lines]] |first=Elizabeth |last=Merrill |publisher=''ESPN.com'' |date=2009-06-16 |accessdate=2009-06-16| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090618050935/http://sports.espn.go.com/golf/usopen09/news/story?id=4260509| archivedate= 18 June 2009 | deadurl= no}} Stewart was memorialized at the Tour Championship with a lone [[bagpipe]] player playing at the first hole at [[Champions Golf Club]] prior to the beginning of the first day of play. The owner of the crash site, after consulting the wives of Stewart and several other victims, created a memorial on about {{convert|1|acre|m2}} of the site. At its center is a rock pulled from the site inscribed with the names of the victims and a Bible passage. The 2000 [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]], held at [[Pebble Beach Golf Links]], began with a golf version of a [[21-gun salute]] when 21 of Stewart's fellow players simultaneously hit balls into the Pacific Ocean. In 2001, Stewart was posthumously inducted into the [[World Golf Hall of Fame]]. On June 8, 2005, a Florida state court jury in Orlando found that Learjet was not liable for the deaths of Stewart and his agents Robert Fraley and Van Ardan, who had also been aboard the plane.{{cite web |url=http://web02.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_generic.jsp?channel=awst&id=news/06135p5.xml&headline=Bombardier%20Not%20Negligent%20in%20Payne%20Stewart%20Crash |title=Bombardier Not Negligent in Payne Stewart Crash |publisher=''aviationweek.com'' |date=2005-06-13 |accessdate=2010-12-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707195702/http://web02.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_generic.jsp?channel=awst&id=news%2F06135p5.xml&headline=Bombardier%20Not%20Negligent%20in%20Payne%20Stewart%20Crash |archive-date=2011-07-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==Documentaries== The documentary series ''[[Mayday (Canadian TV series)|Mayday]],'' also known by the titles ''Air Crash Investigation'' and ''Air Disasters,'' features this incident in the first episode of its 16th season. The episode, titled "[[List of Mayday episodes#ep131|Deadly Silence]]," was first transmitted on 7 June 2016. == See also == *[[Bo Rein]] *[[2000 Australia Beechcraft King Air crash]] *[[Helios Airways Flight 522]] == References == {{Reflist|2}} {{NTSB}} == External links == *[http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/AAB0001.pdf National Transportation Safety Board Aircraft Accident Brief] *[http://www.ntsb.gov/Events/2000/aberdeen/ppt_presentations.htm NTSB Boardmeeting presentation slide show on the crash] *[http://www.ntsb.gov/search/search.asp?TextRestriction=47654&searchfield=dockeywords&CiS1=%2F&CiMaxRecordsPerPage=10&SortProperty=rank&SortOrder=%5Bd%5D&CiTemplateChoice=4&HTMLQueryForm=%2Fntsb%2Fmajor.asp Listing of NTSB resources on the crash] *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/485518.stm Ghost plane's flight to disaster]," ''[[BBC News]]'', 1999-10-25 {{Aviation incidents and accidents in 1999}} {{DEFAULTSORT:South Dakota Learjet Crash}} [[Category:Learjet aircraft]] [[Category:Aviation accidents and incidents in South Dakota]] [[Category:Aviation accidents and incidents in the United States in 1999]] [[Category:Airliner accidents and incidents caused by pilot incapacitation]] [[Category:Decompression accidents and incidents]] [[Category:Edmunds County, South Dakota]] [[Category:1999 in South Dakota|Learjet crash]] [[Category:October 1999 events]]

{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Beth Doe | honorific_suffix = | image = File:Beth Doe.jpg | image_size = | alt = Digital image created from study of morgue photographs to depict an estimation of the victim in life | caption = Most recent facial reconstruction of the victim, created in May 2015 (nose is an approximation). | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1951 - 1962 (approximate) | birth_place = | disappeared_date = | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status ={{Unidentified for|1976|12|20}} | death_date = {{circa}} December 13–19, 1976 | death_place = | death_cause = [[Strangulation]] | body_discovered = December 20, 1976 | resting_place = Laurytown Road Cemetery, Weatherly, Carbon County, Pennsylvania, USA | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = Unidentified victim of homicide | height = {{height|ft=4|in=11|abbr=mos}} (minimum)
{{height|ft=5|in=4|abbr=mos}} (maximum) | weight = {{convert|140|lb|kg}} to {{convert|150|lb|kg}} | children = 1 (at least; unborn) | website = [https://www.facebook.com/carboncountybeth Facebook] }} '''Beth Doe''' (known officially as '''Incident No. N3-27244'''){{cite news|via=Newspapers.com|title=Seek Help on Identities of Victims|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=1365002|accessdate=13 April 2015|work=Lebanon Daily News|date=28 December 1976|page=2}}{{open access}} is the name given to an unidentified young European-American woman who was found murdered on December 20, 1976, in [[White Haven, Pennsylvania]]. The brutality of the crime, the fact that she was pregnant when she was killed and the length of time that she has remained unidentified created national attention.{{cite web|last1=Dudiak|first1=Zandy|title=Unsolved Cases: A New Weekend Patch Feature|url=http://patch.com/pennsylvania/northhills/unsolved-cases-a-new-weekend-patch-feature-5f25f7b9|website=North Hills Patch|accessdate=17 January 2015}} Beth Doe is believed to have been an immigrant from a Central European country. ==Death and discovery== When discovered, Beth Doe, who was carrying a nine-month female [[fetus]], had been sexually assaulted, strangled and shot in the neck by an unknown person.{{cite web|title=MEDIA RELEASE #1956, UNIDENTIFIED BETH DOE AND FEMALE FETUS, EAST SIDE BOROUGH, CARBON COUNTY, PA|url=https://www.crimewatchpa.com/crimestoppers/316/cases/media-release-1956-unidentified-beth-doe-and-female-fetus-east-side-borough-carbon-county|website=crimewatchpa.com|publisher=Pennsylvania Crime Stoppers|accessdate=20 March 2017|date=28 September 2016}} Her body was then dismembered with a serrated blade.{{cite web|title=Beth Doe, Carbon County|url=http://thepennsylvaniarambler.blogspot.com/2011/07/beth-doe-carbon-county.html|publisher=Blogger|accessdate=1 December 2014|date=4 July 2011}} Her nose, breasts, and ears had been severed and have never been found. The dismemberment was described to be unlike that of a surgeon, but not "haphazard." The parts of her body and that of her unborn daughter had been placed into three suitcases; two were striped with red, blue, and white, and the other one was tan with a plaid design.{{cite news|title=Investigators release new images to help solve decades old murder|url=http://www.wfmz.com/news/Regional-Poconos-Coal/investigators-release-new-images-to-help-solve-decades-old-murder/33032228|accessdate=19 July 2015|work=69 News WFMZ-TV|date=14 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150719071233/http://www.wfmz.com/news/Regional-Poconos-Coal/investigators-release-new-images-to-help-solve-decades-old-murder/33032228|archive-date=2015-07-19|dead-url=yes|df=}} They were of vinyl material and were of the same size.{{cite news|last1=O'Neill|first1=Helen|title=Amateur sleuths name anonymous dead|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/media/news196.html|accessdate=14 June 2014|agency=[[Newsweek Magazine]]|date=30 March 2008}} It was evident that the suitcases had been spray-painted black at some point and that their handles had been severed.{{cite news|via=Newspapers.com|title=State Police Seek Aid in Identifying Body|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=1364975|accessdate=19 July 2015|work=The Pocono Record|date=28 December 1976}}{{open access}} To dispose of the body, the suitcases had been thrown off a bridge over the [[Lehigh River]] in [[White Haven, Pennsylvania]] along [[Interstate 80]].{{cite news|last1=O'Neil|first1=Helen|title=Amateur sleuths restore identity to the dead|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/news/article/Amateur-sleuths-restore-identity-to-the-dead-3219899.php|accessdate=23 July 2015|work=Seatle Pi|date=30 March 2008}}{{cite news|title=Identity Unknown|via=Newspapers.com|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/43838129/|accessdate=1 December 2014|work=Simpson's Leader-Times|date=30 December 1976}}{{open access}} They had fallen about 300 feet before hitting the ground.{{cite news|via=newspapers.com|title=State News Summary|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=1364979|accessdate=18 July 2015|work=Evening Herald|date=22 December 1976}}{{open access}} It is believed that the suitcases had been thrown out of a vehicle traveling west. The killer had most likely intended to have the suitcases land in the water below, to lessen the chance of their being found.{{cite news|via=Newspapers.com|title=Bizarre Incident Stumps Police|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=1364962|accessdate=19 July 2015|work=New Castle News|date=28 December 1976|page=5}}{{open access}} Two of the suitcases had landed in the woods, 20 feet from the river; the third, containing the head and fetus, was found on the river bank.{{cite web|title='Carbon County Jane Beth Doe'-A Vidi-Minitary|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cfxp4Brt0-A|website=Youtube|accessdate=1 December 2014|date=31 August 2007}} Having fallen a long distance, two of the suitcases had opened and parts of the body had emerged. The head, fetus, and the two halves of the torso were exposed.{{cite news|last1=Landauer|first1=Bill|title=Investigators close in on Beth Doe and her killer|url=http://www.mcall.com/news/local/mc-carbon-county-beth-doe-20141129-story.html#page=1|accessdate=1 December 2014|work=The Morning Call|date=29 November 2014}} Other evidence included straw, packaging foam, a bedspread, and waterlogged fragments of a newspaper later determined to have been ''The New York Sunday'' from September 26, 1976.{{cite web| last=Warder| first=Robin| title=10 Mysterious Cases Involving Unidentified People| url=http://listverse.com/2013/06/14/10-mysterious-cases-involving-unidentified-people/| accessdate=8 April 2014| date=14 June 2013}} The bedding and newspaper fragments had been wrapped over some of the body parts.{{cite news|via=Newspapers.com|title=Dismembered Body and Fetus Found by Boy|page=14|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=1364964|accessdate=19 July 2015|work=The Evening Times|date=21 December 1976}}{{open access}} The newspaper was linked to the northern part of New Jersey, where the perpetrator may have had ties. The bedspread in the suitcases had a reddish-orange color, was made of [[chenille fabric]], and was wrapped around some of the body. It had yellow and pink embroidered flowers. ==Investigation== [[File:Beth Doe suitcases.jpg|thumb|300px|Reconstructions of the three suitcases in which Beth Doe was found.]] After the body was found, the victim was fingerprinted. Her teeth were examined and recorded on a dental chart.{{cite news|title=Dismembered Body Found Near I-80|via=Newspapers.com|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=1364992|accessdate=13 April 2015|work=The Daily News|date=22 December 1976|page=3}} {{open access}}{{cite news|title=Police Seek Identity for Dismembered Body|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=1365014|accessdate=23 December 2014|work=York Daily Record|via=Newspapers.com|date=22 December 1976}}{{open access}} Missing persons reports throughout the United States and Canada were compared at the time to the victim but were excluded.{{cite news |title=Police Ponder Grizzly Puzzle |work=The Titusville Herald |date=7 January 1977}} The medical examiner noted that a set of numbers had been written on the victim's body. The ink, believed to have been from a pen, was on the left hand of the victim, indicating that she was right-handed if she had indeed written it herself. The writing consisted of the letters '''WSR''' and the number '''4''' or '''5''', followed by '''4''' or '''7'''. Her fingerprints were submitted to the [[FBI]], but they did not match anyone in national databases.{{cite news|via=Newspapers.com|title=State Police try to Identify Dismembered Pregnant Woman|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=1365009|accessdate=23 December 2014|work=York Daily Record|date=28 December 1976}}{{open access}} When she remained unidentified, a sketch was made and the public was asked for assistance. This resulted in few solid leads. Information about the case was subsequently published across the country to generate leads.{{cite news|via=Newspapers.com|title=PSP Seeking Identity of Murdered Woman|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=1364973|accessdate=19 July 2015|work=The Daily Courier|date=28 December 1976}}{{open access}} The body was buried in 1983 after the victim remained unidentified for a number of years.{{cite news|title=Body Found in '76 Buried in Carbon|work=The Morning Call|date=19 August 2983|location=Allentown, Pennsylvania}} In 2007, her remains were exhumed to obtain additional forensic evidence and to create a new facial reconstruction.{{cite news|last1=Rubinkam|first1=Michael|title=30 years later, woman's body exhumed|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/nation/2007-10-30-3230043730_x.htm|accessdate=1 December 2014|work=Associated Press|agency=USA Today}}{{cite web|last1=Whalen|first1=Jill|title=Composite sketch might shed some light|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/media/news154.html|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=14 June 2014|date=20 November 2007}} The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children released two reconstructions, the latest in May 2015.{{cite news|last1=Warner|first1=Frank|title=Images may help ID woman found dismembered in Carbon County in 1976|url=http://www.mcall.com/news/breaking/mc-carbon-i-80-dismembered-beth-doe-20150514-story.html|accessdate=13 July 2015|work=The Morning Call|date=14 May 2015}} Eleven [[Missing person|missing women]] have been excluded as a possible identity of Beth Doe: * Annastaes Banitskas of Australia{{cite web | url=http://doenetwork.org/cases-int/31dfvic.html | title=Case File 31DFVIC | work=[[The Doe Network]] | accessdate=January 5, 2016}} * Iris Brown of Vermont * Valerie Cuccia of New York * Teresa Fittin of Florida * Trenny Gibson of Tennessee * Rory Kesinger of Massachusetts * Anna Leatherwood of Tennessee * Georgia Nolan of Kentucky * Mary Robinson of New York * Patricia Seelbaugh of Pennsylvania * Denise Sheehy of New York{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 8913|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/8913|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=1 December 2014|date=11 July 2011}} ==Examination and physical description== [[File:Beth Doe original.jpg|thumb|left|Original sketch of the victim, created around the time her body was found.]] {{external media | align = left | width | image1= [https://api.missingkids.org/photographs/NCMU1104191x1.jpg 2015 reconstruction with long hair] | image2 = [http://api.missingkids.org/photographs/NCMU1104191x3.jpg Reconstructed bedding] | image3 = [https://www.namus.gov/api/CaseSets/NamUs/UnidentifiedPersons/Cases/8913/Images/33266/Original Previous reconstruction] }} The body was removed by authorities and transported in plastic bags to the nearby Gnadden Huetten Hospital for examination.{{cite news|title=Body Found on Highway|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=1364998|accessdate=13 April 2015|work=Lebanon Daily News|date=22 December 1976|page=25}} {{open access}} After a three-hour [[autopsy]] on December 23, 1976, it was determined that she was a white woman in her late teens or early twenties. However, her identity could not be established.{{cite news|via=Newspapers.com|title=Dismembered body was girl who died of strangulation|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=1365013|accessdate=23 December 2014|work=The Evening Times|date=23 December 1976}}{{open access}}{{cite news|title=Dismembered Body Found By Children in Carbon Co.|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=1364994|accessdate=13 April 2015|work=The Gettysburg Times|date=21 December 1976|page=3}}{{open access}}{{cite news|title=Bodies Found|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=1365005|accessdate=13 April 2015|work=The Evenings Standard|date=21 December 1976}}{{open access}} The cause of death was determined to be that of strangulation, although she had been shot in the neck as well.{{cite news|title=Identified|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=1365006|accessdate=13 April 2015|work=Pottstown Mercury|date=24 December 1976|pages=10}}{{open access}} Beth Doe was between 4 feet 11 inches and 5 feet 4 inches tall. She weighed 140 to 150 pounds (due to her pregnancy).{{cite web| title=Case File 169UFPA| url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/169ufpa.html| work=[[The Doe Network]]| accessdate=29 April 2014}} Her hair, which was shoulder-length, was an undyed dark brown. The medical examiner classified her blood as type O. She had some distinctive markings on her body. A 2- to 6-inch scar was visible above one of her heels.{{cite news|via=Newspapers.com|title=Autopsy Completed|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=1364982|accessdate=13 April 2015|work=The Pocono Record|date=24 December 1976|page=13}}{{open access}} Two [[Mole (skin marking)|moles]] on her face - one above her left eye and one on her left cheek - may have developed during her pregnancy. Before becoming a teen, some of her [[Molar (tooth)|molars]] had been extracted, and she had received fillings in her teeth. No [[Bridge (dentistry)#Bridges|false teeth]] were in place. Despite the evidence of previous care, she had likely not seen a dentist in some time, as she was suffering from severe tooth decay.{{cite web|title=Jane Doe 1976|url=http://www.missingkids.com/poster/NCMU/1104191/1#poster|website=missingkids.com|publisher=[[National Center for Missing and Exploited Children]]|accessdate=31 July 2014}} One of her front incisors had a visible fracture, which was noted to likely cause severe pain. It is believed that she was probably born in Europe and moved to the United States before reaching her teenage years, as examination of her [[tooth enamel]] indicated. An initial anthropological examination indicated she may have originated from Serbia or Croatia. [[Isotope]] testing was conducted on her hair, teeth, and bones.{{cite news|last1=McLaughlin|first1=Eliott C.|title=Did Florida boys school officials send family a casket filled with wood?|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/10/09/us/pennsylvania-dozier-school-for-boys-exhumation/index.html?hpt=hp_t1|accessdate=17 January 2015|publisher=CNN|date=9 October 2014}} She had lived in the U.S. for 5 to 10 years, and most likely had resided in [[Tennessee]] or a nearby state.{{cite web| title="Beth Doe" Carbon County - December 20, 1976| url=http://pennsylvaniamissing.com/carboncountybethdoe.html| accessdate=29 April 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Rubinkham|first1=Michael|title=30 years later, pregnant murder victim still without a name|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/media/news190.html|accessdate=14 June 2014|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=28 December 2006}}{{cite news|title=Artist's conception|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=1364978|accessdate=13 April 2015|work=Evening Herald|date=30 December 1978|pages=9}}{{open access}} Examination on the unborn girl indicated that the child had gestated while the victim was in the Southeastern part of the country. ==See also== * [[List of murdered American children]] * [[Murder of Erica Green]] (a young girl who was murdered in a similar manner in 2001 and was unidentified until 2005) ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category|Unidentified murder victims}} *{{NCMEC UID|1104191}} *{{Doe Network|169ufpa.html}} *{{NamUs|8913}} *{{Find a Grave|23646820}} *{{Find a Grave|121583346|Beth Doe's daughter}} {{Unidentified decedent}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Doe, Beth}} [[Category:1950s births]] [[Category:1976 deaths]] [[Category:1976 in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:1976 murders in the United States]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Deaths by strangulation in the United States]] [[Category:Formerly missing people found dead]] [[Category:Incidents of violence against women]] [[Category:Interstate 80]] [[Category:Murdered American children]] [[Category:People from Carbon County, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:People murdered in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:People who were forensically reconstructed]] [[Category:Sexual assaults in the United States]] [[Category:Unidentified American children]] [[Category:Unidentified murder victims in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Unsolved murders in the United States]] [[Category:Violence against women in the United States]] [[Category:Female murder victims]] [[Category:1960s births]]

In catering, '''beverage functions''' are [[social event|function]]s where beverages are served.
== Who pays == One important issue of beverage functions is who pays for the drinks.<ref name=Idiots>{{cite book|title=The Complete Idiot's Guide to Meeting and Event Planning|author=Robin E. Craven and Lynn Johnson Golabowski|pages=192|publisher=Alpha Books|date=2001|isbn13=9780028640044}}</ref> There are three main scenarios: *a cash bar (a.k.a. a no-host bar): Attendees pay for their own drinks.<ref name=Idiots/><ref>{{cite encyclopedia|article=cash bar|encyclopedia=Dictionary of Travel, Tourism and Hospitality|author=S. Medlik|pages=33|publisher=Butterworth-Heinemann|date=2003|isbn13=9780750656504}}</ref> *a cash bar with tickets: The host issues vouchers to attendees for a limited number of free drinks, and attendees pay for any further drinks themselves.<ref name=Idiots/> *a host bar (a.k.a. an open bar): The host pays for all drinks, either by the hour, by the bottle, by the drink, or per person.<ref name=Idiots/><ref>{{cite encyclopedia|article=host bar|encyclopedia=Dictionary of Travel, Tourism and Hospitality|author=S. Medlik|pages=86|publisher=Butterworth-Heinemann|date=2003|isbn13=9780750656504}}</ref><ref name=BlackTie/>
Choosing among the several options is influenced by several factors. One such factor is etiquette. Providing a cash bar at a function such as a wedding reception is generally considered poor etiquette in the United States.<ref name=Leigh>{{cite book|title=How to Plan Your Own Wedding and Save Thousands|author=Tracy Leigh|publisher=Atlantic Publishing Company|date=2008|isbn13=9781601380074|pages=207–208}}</ref>
Another such factor is cost. A cash bar is the least expensive option for a host. However, there are alternatives between a cash bar and a fully open bar that can limit costs. The host can set a hard limit on cost, beyond which all beverages have to be paid for by attendees. The host can specify that specific beverages, such as a few selected types of wines and beers, are paid for by the host, and that attendees pay for all other types of drinks. The host can set a time limit for an open bar, beyond which it reverts to being a cash bar. Or more complex combinations of these can be employed.<ref name=Leigh/>
Some venues, such as hotels, subject to the terms of their [[liquor license]]s, may allow attendees to bring their own alcoholic drinks to beverage functions. However, they may also charge attendees a fee, usually charged per bottle (either at a flat rate or as a percentage of the bottle's price), for doing so, known as [[corkage]].<ref name=BlackTie/>
Cash bars have their problems for caterers and venue managers. One major problem is the possibility of theft. To prevent this, managers can set up cashiers, who take money and issue drinks tickets, separate from the serving staff who actually serve drinks. Brown and Godsmark recommend to managers that they place only their most trustworthy staff in charge of the cash bars at banquets.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Food Service Manager's Guide to Creative Cost Cutting|author=Douglas Robert Brown|pages=460|publisher=Atlantic Publishing Company|date=2005|isbn13=9780910627610}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Controlling Liquor, Wine & Beverage Costs|author=Douglas Robert Brown and Elizabeth Godsmark|pages=123|publisher=Atlantic Publishing Company|date=2002|isbn13=9780910627184}}</ref>
Conversely, open bars have problems for hosts, in that they can result in an increased number of intoxicated, and potentially obnoxious and aggressive, attendees, as compared to other options. With open bars, the level of waste also increases (which is reflected in increased costs to the host). Since attendees do not pay for their drinks, they often do not consider them to be as valuable as they would if they had paid for them themselves. This results in drinks being abandoned or forgotten, or simply discarded by guests who leave their drinks (as they go and do something else) after only partly consuming them and then replace them with fresh ones rather than finishing the drinks that they already had.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Everything Wedding Organizer|author=Shelly Hagen|pages=135–138|publisher=Everything Books|date=2006|isbn13=9781593376406}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=E-Plan Your Wedding|author=Crystal Melendez and Jason Melendez|pages=218|publisher=Mediasoft Press|date=2007|isbn13=9781933457000}}</ref>
== Types of drinks served == The types of drinks served at functions can vary, according to the type of the event, and the types and ages of the attendees. In particular, at wedding receptions whether the bride and groom are themselves alcohol drinkers can affect whether attendees pay for their own alcoholic drinks, or indeed whether alcohol is offered at all. Similarly, alcohol is not served at beverage events for children.<ref name=Leigh/><ref name=BlackTie/>
Another factor that affects whether alcohol is served is liability, for subsequent intoxication and anything that results from it. Many U.S. jurisdictions allow the victims of accidents to sue not only the person who was intoxicated, but also the person who served the alcohol, the person or company employing the bartender, and the board of directors of the company.<ref name=BlackTie>{{cite book|title=Black Tie Optional|author=Harry A. Freedman and Karen Feldman|pages=122–123|publisher=Wiley-Interscience|date=2007|isbn13=9780470116814}}</ref>
