(closed 1973–1980s) |yearsactive = 95 approx |rebuilt = |closed = 2008 |production = |currentuse = Vacant |website = [http://salfordvictoria.co.uk/ Save the Victoria Theatre Trust] }} The '''Victoria Theatre, Salford''', is a theatre in the [[Broughton, Salford|Lower Broughton]] area of [[Salford, Greater Manchester]], England. It is situated on Great Clowes Street, on the corner of the Elton Street. The theatre officially opened 10 December 1900 and was last in use as a bingo hall in 2008. The original capacity was 2,000 seated, this was increased to 3,000 in 1910. Palatial Leisure Limited sold the building in September 2018. == Background == The Victoria Theatre, designed by [[Bertie Crewe]], was built by The Broughton Theatres Syndicate Ltd,{{cite web | last = Staff writer | title = Victoria Theatre (Salford) | url =http://www.theatrestrust.org.uk/resources/theatres/show/1829-victoria-theatre-salford | website = theatrestrust.org.uk | publisher = [[Theatres Trust]] | date = 2015 |accessdate= 3 April 2016 }} the same syndicate which controlled the [[Frank Matcham#Career|Regent Theatre]], Cross Lane, Salford (destroyed by fire in 1952).{{cite web | title = The Regent Theatre of Varieties, and Assembly Rooms, Cross Lane, Salford | url = http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/SalfordTheatres.htm#regent | website = arthurlloyd.co.uk | publisher = Arthur Lloyd |accessdate= 3 April 2016 }} The building's foundation stone was laid on 4 October 1899 by the actor [[Henry Irving|Sir Henry Irving]]. Accompanying Irving was [[Bram Stoker]], also in attendance were Bertie Crewe, the Civic Mayor of Salford [[Civic mayor of Salford#Mayors of Salford|Samuel Rudman]], [[Frederick Platt-Higgins]] ([[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[Member of Parliament|MP]] for [[Salford North (UK Parliament constituency)|Salford North]]), C. V. Haworth (chairman of the syndicate), a large number of the members from the Salford Corporation, and former Civic Mayors of Salford [[Civic mayor of Salford#Mayors of Salford|Sir W. H. Bailey]] and [[Civic mayor of Salford#Mayors of Salford|Sir Richard Mottram]]. Crewe presented Irving with a mallet and a silver trowel. In a short speech Irving remarked, "I have always contended that a well-conducted playhouse is a centre of rational recreation, and without rational recreation no community can pretend to have its facultics in proper order."{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = New theatre for Broughton: speech by Sir Henry Irving | work = [[The Manchester Guardian]] | publisher = [[ProQuest]] | page = 5 | url = http://search.proquest.com/docview/473575385 | date = 5 October 1899 }} When the application for the theatre's licence was heard by the town council, Mr. J. Broxap put forward an amendment, "That the resolution of the Watch Committee be approved subject to no application being made to the Excise for the licence to sell intoxicating drink." The amendment was seconded by Mr. Haworth who added, "Persons who went in and out to get drink interrupted the performance, to the annoyance of those who desired to see the piece." The council voted 25 for the amendment to alter the theatre's licence so that alcohol could not be sold, 32 against and 1 abstention. The Mayor declared the amendment lost.{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Salford Town Council: The licence of the Broughton Theatre - confirmation by the council | work = [[The Manchester Guardian]] | publisher = [[ProQuest]] | page = 3 | url = http://search.proquest.com/docview/473680545 | date = 31 October 1900 }} The 2,000 seater theatre opened on 10 December 1900 with the play "''[[The Sign of the Cross (play)|Sign of the Cross]]''," performed by [[William Greet]]'s company, with Edward Vincent as the Prefect and Virginia Buckle as the Christian girl Mercia. The front of the theatre was described as "red terra-cotta, divided by [[Pilaster|Ionic pilasters]] into five bays" and the foyer was described as "a hall 34 feet long and 18 feet wide, with marble mosaic floor, walls panelled in fibrous plaster, and hand-painted ceiling". The dimensions of the stage were also recorded as "Its width is 74 feet, the distance from the curtain line to the back wall is 40 feet, the distance from stage to grid is 50 feet, and the proscenium opening is 30 feet in width.{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Opening of the Victoria Theatre, Broughton | work = [[The Manchester Guardian]] | publisher = [[ProQuest]] |page = 4 | url = http://search.proquest.com/docview/473713520 | date = 11 December 1900 }} == Use as a cinema == In November 1901, less than a year after opening, the theatre began showing films and in 1913 it was granted a cinema licence.{{cite web | title = Victoria Theatre | url = http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/2056 | website = cinematreasures.org | publisher = Cinema Treasures | access-date = 6 August 2016 }} The owner/managers, Messrs J. P. Moore & Montague Beadyn, also increased the capacity in 1910 from 2,000 to 3,000. However, from 1917 to 1919 the venue became a theatre once more. In 1919 the theatre consultant Mr. Watson redesigned the auditorium with interior paintings and a Tudor Café and the theatre became predominantly a cinema again under H. D. Moorhouse,{{cite news | last = Parkinson | first = J. A. | title = Letter to the editor: Victoria Theatre, Salford | work = [[Theatres Trust#Publications|Theatres Magazine]] | issue = 34 | page = 28 | publisher = The Theatres Trust Charitable Fund | format = pdf | url = http://www.theatrestrust.org.uk/store/assets/0000/3482/Theatres_Magazine_No.34.pdf | date = Winter 2012 }} and remained a cinema until its closure in July 1958.{{cite web | title = The Victoria Theatre, 14-18 Great Clowes Street, Salford | url = http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/SalfordTheatres.htm#victoria | website = arthurlloyd.co.uk | publisher = Arthur Lloyd |accessdate= 3 April 2016 }} The owner/managers from 1945 were Broughton Cinemas Ltd. == 1958–1971 == Following the cinema's closure in July 1958 the theatre was used as a clothing / furniture store with some performances by repertory groups, including Venture Productions, and pantomimes being staged during the 1960s. From the mid 1960s until the summer of 1971, the theatre was owned by a Salford businessman, Councillor Sam Goldberg. Goldberg allowed repertory groups such as Venture Productions to put on productions rent free.{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Warehouse may be theatre again: company accepts offer | work = [[The Guardian]] | publisher = [[ProQuest]] | page = 10 | url = http://search.proquest.com/docview/184767720 | date = 19 August 1961 }} He also used the theatre as winter headquarters for his own Southport Repertory Company.{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Salford loses last theatre | work = [[The Guardian]] | publisher = [[ProQuest]] | page = 6 | url = http://search.proquest.com/docview/185463291 | date = 30 December 1970 }} Goldberg tried unsuccessfully to sell the freehold to Salford City Council, in the hope that they might operate the building as a civic theatre and arts centre. Talks stalled after it was estimated that the cost of modernising the building could be about £80,000, the theatre was running at a loss at the time of Goldberg's death.{{cite web | title = Victoria Theatre Salford (blog) | url = http://www.laughingaudience.co.uk/victoria-theatre-salford.html | website = laughingaudience.co.uk | publisher = Laughing Audience |accessdate= 3 April 2016 }} Councillor Cecil Franks, the chairman, said it was hopeless to try to maintain a "Victorian relic" of this size in its present form.{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Salford may lose theatre | work = [[The Observer]] | publisher = [[ProQuest]] | page = 5 | url = http://search.proquest.com/docview/185581918 | date = 27 October 1970 }} Goldberg died prior to the North Manchester Amateur Operatic Society's production of "''[[The Quaker Girl]]''", May–June 1971, (music by [[Lionel Monckton]], lyrics by [[Adrian Ross]] and [[Percy Greenbank]]), the theatre then lay dark. == Use as a bingo hall == After a brief unsuccessful attempt to run the venue as a bingo hall in 1973 the theatre closed again. It then remained dark until the 1980s when a second attempt was successful and the bingo hall remained open until 2008. The theatre became a [[Listed building#Categories of listed building|Grade II Listed Building]] on 18 January 1980.{{cite web | title = Former Victoria Theatre | url = https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1386137 | website = historicengland.org.uk | publisher = [[Historic England]] |accessdate= 3 April 2016 }} During its time as a bingo hall in the 1980s the building was severely damaged when its third floor was removed and replaced with a less ornate brick wall.{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Salford residents rally to save historic local theatre | work = [[ATV Today]] | publisher = [[Associated Television|ATV]] | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160514034751/http://www.atvtoday.co.uk/1900-salford-residents-rally-to-save-historic-local-theatre-68/ | archive-date = 14 May 2016 | url = http://www.atvtoday.co.uk/1900-salford-residents-rally-to-save-historic-local-theatre-68/ | date = 25 August 2012 }} == 2008–2012 == [[File:Mocha Parade - geograph.org.uk - 180519.jpg|thumb|right|Mocha Parade, facing the theatre, 2009]] Palatial Leisure Limited closed down Victoria Bingo Hall in 2008 and have since carried out work on the roof; however, urgent repairs are currently{{When|date=May 2016}} needed to deal with the plant growth on the venue's facade. The front canopy was also destroyed after a truck collided with it. In 2012 Palatial Leisure Limited decided to put the theatre on the market for £275,000.{{cite book | title = For sale: former Victoria Theatre plus two self contained retail units gross external area circa 11,500ft² | url = http://www.wtgunson.co.uk/webroot/content/properties/documents/Great%20Clowes%20St%2014-18-120726-095108.pdf | format = pdf | publisher = W. T. Gunson (estate agent) | date = 12 June 2012 }}{{cite AV media | people= Zarrion Walker (presenter) and Tony Flynn (Salford historian and writer) | date= 1 August 2012 |accessdate= 3 April 2016 | title= Save Salford Victoria Theatre | medium= Video | publisher= Quays News via [[YouTube]] | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_HlBTl0FN7I }}{{Cite episode |title= Campaign to Save Salford Victoria Theatre |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p002mwyt |series= Beswick at Breakfast | people= [[Allan Beswick]] (presenter), Ruth Clegg (reporter) and David Dewsnip (guest) |station= [[BBC]]|network= [[BBC Radio Manchester]]|date= 13 August 2012 |time= 07.47am |transcript= Transcript: '''Ruth Clegg:''' "David we've had a look around the theatre, a quick tour and it is grotty, it is dilapidated, it has that smell a kind of musty flooding smell but it's got many of it's Victorian features, it's quite a sorry state really isn't it?" '''David Dewsnip:''' "It is a sorry state, recently it has been vandalised - a lot of the cast iron pipe work and the electrical cables have been taken, which is a shame. It caused a lot of flooding and disrepair to the room. I think once it is opened up and it is watertight again, completely watertight, a lot of that musty smell will start to go once there is air circulating through the building." }} (10 minute interview.) In the same year the [[Theatres Trust]] placed the Victoria Theatre (Salford) on their Theatre Buildings at Risk (TBAR) register, although it was in the lowest of their four categories.{{cite news | last = Cranna | first = Ailsa | title = Theatre campaigners' bid to get curtains rising again | work = [[Salford Advertiser]] | page = 22 | publisher = [[Trinity Mirror]] | date = 26 July 2012}}{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Campaign to save Salford's Victoria Theatre | work = [[Theatres Trust#Publications|Theatres Magazine]] | issue = 33 | page = 23 | publisher = The Theatres Trust Charitable Fund | format = pdf | url = http://www.theatrestrust.org.uk/store/assets/0000/3026/TM33_Autumn2012.pdf | date = Autumn 2012 }} The Theatres Trust noted that several of the theatre's original features are still intact, "There are substantial remains of wooden sub-stage machinery with paddle levers and the construction for corner traps and four bridges. The grave trap is complete with its platform."; they also noted the need for regeneration in the area surrounding the theatre. A 'Save Victoria Theatre Campaign Meeting' was held on 1 August 2012 at the [[University of Salford#Facilities|Robert Powell Theatre]], [[University of Salford]].{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Salford Victoria Theatre at risk | url = http://www.salfordstar.com/article.asp?id=1459 | work = Salford Star | date = 29 July 2012 }}{{cite AV media | people= Tony Flynn (presenter), Allen Christey (guest), Micky Dacks (guest), and Jo Hill, [[Architectural Heritage Fund]] (guest) | date= 24 July 2012 |accessdate= 1 May 2016 | title= Campaign ramps up to Save Salford Victoria Theatre | medium= Video | publisher= SalfordOnline | url = http://archive.salfordonline.com/localnews_page/37219-video:_campaign_ramps_up_to_save_salford_victoria_theatre.html }} The meeting resulted in the formation of a community group, Save the Victoria Theatre Salford (SVTS).{{cite book | last = Staff writer | title = The Theatres Trust Building at Risk Register 2015 (press information): Victoria Theatre, Salford | url =http://www.theatrestrust.org.uk/store/assets/0000/4751/03_2015_TAR_9_Victoria_Theatre_Salford.pdf | format = pdf | publisher = [[Theatres Trust]] | date = 2015 }} In the group were David Dewsnip, a production technician at the University of Salford, who called the meeting, and Allen Christey, an electrical engineer, who was involved in a failed attempt to save the theatre from being turned into a bingo hall in 1971.{{cite news | last = Merrifield | first = Nicola | title = Campaign mounted to save Salford theatre | url = http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/newsstory.php/36985/campaign-mounted-to-save-salford-theatre | work = [[The Stage]] | publisher = The Stage Media Company Ltd | date = 8 August 2012 }} Following the meeting a steering group was set up with Dewsnip and Christey as joint leaders, the rest of the steering group was named as: Roland Metcalf, Bob Howorth, [[Salford City Council election, 2016#Claremont|Mary Ferrer]], Estelle Neuman and Cath Connett.{{cite news | last = Editor | title = Save Salford Victoria Theatre campaign continues apace | url = http://archive.salfordonline.com/localnews_page/37501-save_salford_victoria_theatre_campaign_continues_apace.html | work = SalfordOnline | publisher = [[Community interest company|SalfordOnline CIC]] | date = 8 August 2012 }} However concerns have been raised about how the members of the steering group were selected, such as the non-inclusion of Micky Dacks,{{cite AV media | people= Tony Flynn (presenter), Micky Dacks (guest), Allen Christey (guest), Fred Platt (guest), Brian Thorpe (guest) and David Dewsnip (guest) | date= 6 August 2012 |accessdate= 1 May 2016 | title= Save The Victoria Theatre, Salford meeting | medium= Video | publisher= SalfordOnline | url = http://archive.salfordonline.com/localnews_page/37469-video:_save_the_victoria_theatre,_salford_meeting.html }} and whether or not "the community is being used for the benefit of Salford University".{{cite news | last = Speed | first = Steve | title = Salford Victoria Theatre Campaign: Can lower Broughton's Victoria Theatre be saved? | url = http://www.salfordstar.com/article.asp?id=1463 | work = Salford Star | date = 3 August 2012 }} == 2013–present == In February 2013 Save the Victoria Theatre Salford formed Save the Victoria Theatre Trust (SVTT) to take forward the potential purchase, refurbishment and reopening of the building.{{cite news | last = Flynn | first = Tony | title = Save Salford Victoria Theatre: campaign update | url = http://archive.salfordonline.com/localnews_page/40871-save_salford_victoria_theatre:_campaign_update.html | work = SalfordOnline | publisher = [[Community interest company|SalfordOnline CIC]] | date = 30 January 2013 }} The trust was initially composed of Dewsnip, Christey, Howorth, Ferrer, and John Lucas.{{cite web | title = Salford Victoria Theatre Trust | url = https://companycheck.co.uk/company/08422509/SALFORD-VICTORIA-THEATRE-TRUST/companies-house-data#directors-and-secretaries | website = companycheck.co.uk | publisher = Company Check | access-date = 25 February 2017 }} Palatial Leisure is willing to sell the building to SVTT but they are unable to afford it. In May 2015 [[Salford City Council]] visited the site with a view to serving an Urgent Works Notice. However, the visit showed no evidence of water penetration so the council is considering other options and actions. These have yet to be determined and in the meantime the building is subject to continued deterioration. Ferrer resigned from the trust in January 2014 and Lucas resigned in January 2015. Two new directors, Samantha Kelly and Ray Walker, were appointed in November 2015. {{ external media | topic = News item | video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YcsXe_FcMIQ ''Save the Victoria Theatre Campaign reignites, 11 December 2017''] via Quays News{{cite AV media | people= Jen Smith (Reporter), Allen Christey (Company Secretary, Salford Victoria Theatres Trust), Matthew Holmes (Derelict Explorer) | date= 11 December 2017 |accessdate= 19 September 2018 | title= Save the Victoria Theatre Campaign reignites | medium= Video | publisher= Quays News via [[YouTube]] | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YcsXe_FcMIQ }}}} In December 2017 ''Quays News'' reported that SVTT was being relaunched with the support of [[Salford City Council]]'s mayor [[Paul Dennett]] and the local [[Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)|MP]] [[Graham Stringer]]. However in September 2018 the theatre was put up for auction with a guide price of £350,000{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Salford grade II listed Victoria Theatre goes up for auction | url = http://www.salfordstar.com/article.asp?id=4669 | work = Salford Star | date = 20 August 2018 |accessdate= 19 September 2018}} which prompted the SVTT to campaign to have the building recognized as an '[[asset of community value]]'.{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Salford Victoria Theatre Trust in race to stop auction of grade II listed building | url = http://www.salfordstar.com/article.asp?id=4677 | work = Salford Star | date = 26 August 2018 |accessdate= 19 September 2018}} The council's ''Draft Local Plan'' (2016) document promised protection for the building, "securing its positive reuse, preferably for a community use in keeping with its original function and design",{{cite book | last = Staff writer | chapter = Chapter 5, Area Policies: Policy C1 Cambridge, Broughton | chapter-url = https://www.salford.gov.uk/planning-building-and-regeneration/planning-policies/local-planning-policy/salfords-development-plan/salford-local-plan/draft-local-plan/ | title = A fairer city, Draft Local Plan | pages = 24–25 | publisher = [[Salford City Council]] | date = October 2016}}{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Salford Council Local Plan for next twenty years of development | url = http://www.salfordstar.com/article.asp?id=3535 | work = Salford Star | date = 28 October 2016 |accessdate= 19 September 2018}} but its sale has caused concern within SVTT that the revised plan, due to be published in November 2018, will include a plan to demolish the theatre.{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Salford grade II listed Victoria Theatre sold as campaigners remain cynical | url = http://www.salfordstar.com/article.asp?id=4705 | work = Salford Star | date = 10 September 2018 |accessdate= 19 September 2018}} == Dimensions == The current stage dimensions are as
